body_html:
Thank you @yifeif,
I'm running pip install -U pip before doing anything else on travis. So the pip version is currently the most recent one, 9.0.1.

I agree that the issue you reference is likely to be related, but it seems as if the discussion there doesn't really include a fix that would work on travis. Or am I missing something there?

Also, I'm not quite sure what you mean by "them" when you ask if it is possible to upgrade them on my system. I can locally upgrade anything, but that wouldn't help on travis. Seems like upgrading glibc on travis is a bit of a hassle, but might work.

body:
Thank you @yifeif,
I'm running `pip install -U pip` before doing anything else on travis. So the pip version is currently the most recent one, `9.0.1`.

I agree that the issue you reference is likely to be related, but it seems as if the discussion there doesn't really include a fix that would work on travis. Or am I missing something there?

Also, I'm not quite sure what you mean by "them" when you ask if it is possible to upgrade them on my system. I can locally upgrade anything, but that wouldn't help on travis. Seems like upgrading glibc on travis is a bit of a hassle, but might work.
